questions.text: A 6-year-old child falls on an outstretched hand and presents with pain and swelling around the elbow. X-ray revealed a supracondylar fracture of the humerus. What is the most likely mechanism of injury?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Supracondylar fractures result from a fall on an outstretched hand with a hyperextended elbow.

Supracondylar fractures:

  • The most common elbow fracture in children and is associated with the most complications.
  • Clinical features:
    • Pain and swelling
    • Deformity
    • Anterior pucker sign or brachialis sign: Seen in displaced supracondylar fractures of the humerus and refers to a dimple or puckering of the skin over the anterior aspect of the elbow.

Gartland classification of supracondylar fracture:

  • Type I - Undisplaced fracture
  • Type II - Partially displaced fracture with intact posterior periosteum
  • Type III - Completely displaced

Treatment:

Undisplaced fracture: Immobilisation in an above-elbow plaster slab, with the elbow in 90° flexion.

Displaced fracture:

  • Closed reduction and percutaneous K-wire fixation: Most displaced fractures are easily reduced by closed reduction, but they often slip. Hence, it is best to fix them with one or two K-wires, passed percutaneously under image intensifier guidance.
  • Open reduction and K-wire fixation: In some cases, it is not possible to achieve a good position by closed methods, or the fracture gets redisplaced after reduction. In such cases, open reduction and K-wire fixation are necessary. This is also used as a first line of treatment in some open fractures and those requiring exploration.

Injury around the elbow according to the deforming forces:

choices.text: Loss of sensation over the tip of the little finger

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought to a clinic with a deformity as shown in the image. Parents give a history of an injury around the elbow joint, following which the deformity developed. Which of the following can likely result from the deformity?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The deformity shown in the picture above is cubitus valgus. It is a late complication of the non-union of the lateral condylar fracture of the humerus. Ulnar palsy is a likely complication, which can result in paresthesia at the tip of the little finger.

  • Diminished/ absent growth at the lateral side of the distal humerus epiphysis results in a cubitus valgus deformity.
  • It results in a late-onset ulnar nerve palsy called tardy ulnar nerve palsy. Therefore, anaesthesia at the tip of the little finger, which is the zone of autonomous supply of the ulnar nerve, is a feature.
  • Treatment: At the earliest opportunity, the nerve should be transposed anteriorly from behind the medial epicondyle to prevent friction (anterior transposition of the ulnar nerve).

The opposition thumb is by opponents pollicis, innervated by a recurrent branch of the median nerve and not affected in cubitus valgus deformity. (Option A ruled out)

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with pain and swelling over the elbow after a fall. X-ray revealed a displaced fracture of the lateral condyle of the humerus with loss of articular congruity. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lateral condyle fractures of the humerus are fractures of necessity, which means that they have to be treated with surgical fixation. Conservative treatment can lead to nonunion, resulting in cubitus valgus and tardy ulnar nerve palsy. Thus, open reduction with internal fixation is the best line of management in this case.

Treatment of fracture of the lateral condyle of the humerus:

Undisplaced fracture:

  • The arm is splinted in a backslab with the elbow flexed 90 degrees, the forearm in neutral rotation and the wrist extended - this position relaxes the extensor mechanism, which attaches to the fragment. (Option A ruled out)

Displaced fracture:

  • A displaced fracture requires accurate reduction and internal fixation. (Option B ruled out)
  • If the fragment is only moderately displaced (hinged), it may be possible to manipulate it into position by extending the elbow and pressing upon the condyle, and then fixing the fragment with percutaneous pins.
  • If this fails, and for all separated fractures, open reduction and internal fixation with pins or screws is required.

Fractures of necessity:

  • Lateral condyle fracture humerus
  • Fracture neck femur
  • Galeazzi fracture-dislocation
  • Monteggia fracture in adults

questions.text: A 30-year-old male sustained an external rotation injury to the elbow, resulting in severe pain and swelling around the elbow. If a terrible triad injury of the elbow is suspected, which among the following structures will be involved?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The terrible triad of the elbow is a severe elbow fracture-dislocation pattern with the following features:
    • Posterior elbow dislocation
    • Coronoid process fracture
    • Radial head fracture
  • It is also associated with medial collateral ligament rupture
  • The treatment is usually surgical, with radial head fixation or replacement and lateral ligament repair.

Explanation of other options:

Medial epicondyle (Option B): Fractures of the medial epicondyle of the humerus occur due to traction injuries resulting in an avulsion of the apophysis by the medial collateral ligament and flexor mass. It is often associated with elbow dislocation.

Olecranon (Option C): Typically result from a direct blow to the proximal forearm, and the proximal fragment gets displaced by the triceps pull.

Radial tuberosity (Option D): The biceps tendon inserts into the radial tuberosity, and activities involving forceful contraction of the biceps tendon can result in fractures of the radial tuberosity.

choices.text: It is a subluxation of the radial head
It is treated by fully supinating the forearm

questions.text: A 3-year-old child complains of pain and inability to move his left elbow after his mother grabbed his arm and attempted to lead him across the street. Physical exam demonstrates guarding of the extremity with the elbow held in a flexed and pronated position. Which of the following is not true about the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The likely diagnosis in this child is pulled elbow, which occurred when the mother pulled the child's arm, consequently leading to dislocation of the radial head. An X-ray image is not useful, as it appears normal in the case of a pulled elbow.

Pulled elbow:

  • The pulled elbow, also called nursemaid's elbow, is the subluxation of the radial head out of the annular ligament. (Option A ruled out)
  • Dislocation of the radial head from the annular ligament is a fairly common injury in children under the age of 6 years. There may be a history of the child being jerked by the arm and subsequently complaining of pain and inability to use the arm.
  • It is caused by the axial traction on the extended arm, while the forearm is pronated, such as when a child is pulled at the wrist to prevent a fall or is picked up from the floor by their hand. ((Option D ruled out)
  • The child comes with the forearm in the pronated position, and supination is resisted.
  • Treatment: The head is reduced by fully supinating and flexing the forearm while applying direct pressure over the radial head. (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: A 19-year-old male sustains the isolated, closed injury seen in Figure A. He is subsequently treated as shown in Figure B. When utilising this technique, what forces are generated at the articular surface?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above X-ray images show a simple transverse olecranon fracture appropriately treated with a tension-band construct. This construct converts distraction forces at the joint generated by the pull of the triceps into compression forces.

The change of force into compression requires active motion of the elbow extensor mechanism.

Tension band wiring:

  • A fractured bone has a tension side, i.e., the side which tends to 'open up' on use of the limb, because it is subjected to a distracting force.
  • If this force is countered by some device fixed on the tension side, the fracture comes under compression. This is called the tension-band principle.
  • Dynamic compression can be achieved by the following methods:
    • Tension-band wire: This can be used for producing dynamic compression in fractures of the patella and olecranon.
    • Tension-band plate: This can be used for fractures of the humerus and tibia by applying the plate on the tension surface.

choices.text: Perform closed reduction of the radius, then immobilise the forearm in a long arm cast in supination
Perform open reduction and internal fixation of the radius, then assess the proximal radioulnar joint for instability, and percutaneously fix the proximal radioulnar joint if instability persists
Perform open reduction and internal fixation of the radius, then assess the distal radioulnar joint for instability, and percutaneously fix the distal radioulnar joint if instability persists

questions.text: A 33-year-old man sustains blunt trauma to his forearm and presents with the injury seen in the figure. Definitive management of this injury involves the following:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The picture shown above is a Galeazzi fracture dislocation (reverse Monteggia/Piedmont fracture). Definitive management includes open reduction with internal fixation; if instability of the distal radio-ulnar exists, then it is percutaneously fixed.

Galeazzi fracture:

  • There is a fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.
  • Prominence or tenderness over the lower end of the ulna is the striking feature. It may be possible to demonstrate the instability of the radioulnar joint by 'ballotting' the distal end of the ulna (the 'piano-key sign') or by rotating the wrist.
  • X-rays show a transverse or short oblique fracture in the lower third of the radius, with angulation or overlap. The distal radioulnar joint is subluxated or dislocated.
  • The treatment of choice is open reduction and internal fixation with compression plates.
  • The counterpart of Galeazzi is the Monteggia fracture-dislocation, where there is a fracture of the upper third of the ulna with dislocation of the radial head.
  • Both of these fractures, in adults, are fractures of necessity, i.e., it is necessary to perform open reduction and internal fixation for best results.

Treatment of Galeazzi fracture:

  • In children, closed reduction is often successful.
  • In adults, reduction is best achieved by open operation and compression plating of the radiu An X-ray is taken to ensure that the distal radioulnar joint is reduced. There are three possibilities:
    • The distal radioulnar joint is reduced and stable: No further action is needed. The arm is rested for a few days, then gentle active movements are encouraged.
    • The distal radioulnar joint is reduced but unstable: The forearm should be immobilised in the position of stability, supplemented if required by a transverse K-wire. The forearm is splinted in an above-elbow cast for 6 weeks.
    • The distal radioulnar joint is irreducible: Open reduction is needed to remove the interposed soft tissues. The triangular fibrocartilage complex and dorsal capsule are then carefully repaired, and the forearm is immobilised in the position of stability for 6 weeks.

questions.text: A depressed intra-articular fracture of the lunate fossa of the distal radius is also known as?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A die-punch fracture is a depressed intra-articular fracture of the lunate fossa of the distal radius.

Die-punch fracture:

  • It is named after the machining technique of shearing a shape, depression or hole in a material with a die implement or cutter used in the tool-and-die trade. Here, the lunate is forced into the articulation surface of the distal radius, causing a fracture.

Explanation of other options:

Barton fracture (Option A): Intra-articular fractures through the distal articular surface of the radius, taking a margin, anterior or posterior, of the distal radius with the carpals, displaced anteriorly or posteriorly.

Chauffeur fracture (Option B): An intra-articular, oblique fracture of the styloid process of the radius.

Colles fracture (Option D): A fracture occurring in adults, at the cortico-cancellous junction of the distal end of the radius with dorsal tilt and other displacements

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with pain and swelling around the right wrist joint following a fall. An X-ray of the wrist is shown below. What mechanism most likely led to this injury?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

X-ray shows distal radius and ulna fracture with significant shortening, volar displacement and volar angulation, suggesting Smith's fracture. The mechanism of injury would be a fall onto a flexed wrist, placing volar stress on the wrist.

Smith's fracture:

  • It is caused by a fall on the back of the hand and is an unstable injury due to the force generated by the long flexors crossing the wrist.
  • Also called the reverse Colles' fracture, it differs from Colles' fracture in that the distal fragment displaces ventrally and tilts ventrally.
  • The patient presents with a wrist injury, and there is a 'garden-spade' deformity.
  • Treatment is by closed reduction and plaster cast immobilisation for 6 weeks.

Explanation of other options:

Axial loading of the carpus (Option A): A direct vertical force on the carpus can result in high-energy wrist injuries, as seen in die-punch fracture.

Axial loading of the forearm (Option B): Axial loads through the forearm from a high-energy fall on the hand result in fracture of the radial head and proximal migration of the radius relative to the ulna. This rare injury is associated with rupture of the central condensation of the interosseous membrane of the forearm and is known as the Essex-Lopresti lesion.

Fall on an outstretched hand (Option C): Pain and swelling over the wrist following a fall on an outstretched hand, in an adult, can result in scaphoid fracture or Colles' fracture.

Falling on outstretched hands can also result in fracture of the clavicle, injuries around the elbow, like a supracondylar fracture of the humerus.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female presents with severe pain and swelling of the right wrist following a slip and fall on her outstretched hand. On examination, there is a prominence on the back of the wrist and a depression in the front. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

An alleged history of a slip and fall on an outstretched hand in an elderly person strongly suggests a Colle's fracture. The deformity explained is the dorsal deformity of Colle's fracture.

Colle's fracture:

  • A Colles fracture is a transverse fracture of the distal radius at the cortico-cancellous junction with dorsal angulation and impaction, but without the involvement of the articular surface.
  • It is the most common of all fractures in older people, the high incidence being related to the onset of postmenopausal osteoporosis. Thus, the patient is usually an older woman who gives a history of falling on her outstretched hand.
  • Mechanism of injury and pathological anatomy: Force is applied along the length of the forearm with the wrist in extension. The bone fractures at the corticocancellous junction and the distal fragment collapses into extension, dorsal displacement, radial tilt and shortening.
  • Clinical features:
    • Local tenderness and pain on wrist movements
    • Dinner-fork' deformity, with prominence on the back of the wrist and a depression in front.

Treatment of Colles' fracture:

  • For an undisplaced fracture, immobilisation in a below-elbow plaster cast for six weeks is sufficient.
  • For displaced fractures, the standard method of treatment is manipulative reduction followed by immobilisation in a Colles' cast. In comminuted fractures, surgical stabilisation of fractures with percutaneous K-wire fixation is also required.

Technique of closed manipulation:

  • The muscles of the forearm must be relaxed, either by general or regional anaesthesia. The surgeon grasps the injured hand as if he were 'shaking hands'.
  • The surgeon applies longitudinal traction to disimpact the distal fragment, followed by pronation, palmar flexion and ulnar deviation.
  • A plaster cast is applied extending from below the elbow to the metacarpal heads, maintaining the wrist in palmar flexion and ulnar deviation. This is Colles' cast.

Explanation of other options:

Barton fracture (Option A): Barton fracture is an intraarticular fracture involving the dorsal/ volar lip of the distal radius with subluxation of the carpus and hand bones.

Chauffeur's fracture (Option B): Chauffeur's fracture is an intraarticular fracture of the radial styloid

Die-punch fracture (Option D): A die-punch fracture is a depressed intra-articular fracture of the lunate fossa of the distal radius

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman with a history of Colle's fracture 2 months back, now presents with inability to extend the thumb. Which tendon is most likely ruptured as a late complication of a previous Colle's fracture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rupture of the extensor pollicis longus is a complication of Colle's fracture.

  • Extensor pollicis longus causes extension at the interphalangeal joint of the thumb. It is examined by stabilising the metacarpophalangeal joint of the thumb, while the patient is asked to extend the interphalangeal joint.
  • It is usually associated with a malunited Colles fracture, where the fracture fragment impinges on and abrades the EPL tendon.
  • It commonly occurs in the fourth week after the fracture, though it may present later.

Complications of Colle's fracture:

  • Joint stiffness: Finger stiffness is the most common complication. Wrist, elbow, and shoulder are the other joints that become stiff.
  • Malunion is the second most common complication, and it leads to the "dinner fork' deformity.
  • Sudeck's osteodystrophy/reflex sympathetic dystrophy. Colle's fracture is the most common cause of Sudeck's dystrophy in the upper limb.
  • Rupture of the extensor pollicis longus tendon
  • Carpal instability
  • Triangular-fibro cartilage complex (TFCC) injury and subluxation of the inferior radio-ulnar joint
  • Delayed union and non-union are extremely rare.

Explanation of other options:

Extensor pollicis brevis (Option B): Extensor pollicis brevis helps with extension of the thumb at the metacarpophalangeal joint and is rarely ruptured in Colles fracture.

Abductor pollicis longus (Option C): de Quervain's tenosynovitis is a condition characterised by pain and swelling over the radial styloid process. It results from inflammation of the common sheath of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the trauma bay after falling onto his flexed wrist. What is the eponymous name of the fracture shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The x-ray shows an extra-articular transverse fracture through the distal radius with volar angulation of the distal fracture fragment representing a Smith fracture. An avulsion fracture of the ulnar styloid process can also be seen.

  • The direction of displacement can be assessed on an X-ray by looking at the thickness of soft tissue shadow around the forearm bones on the lateral X-ray.
  • The volar soft tissue shadow will always be thicker than the dorsal soft tissue shadow.
  • So, wherever the soft tissue shadow is thicker, it is volar, and the thinner side would be dorsal.

Smith's fracture (Reverse of Colles' Fracture):

  • This uncommon fracture is seen in adults and in elderly people.
  • Its importance lies in differentiating it from the commoner Colles' fracture, which occurs at the same site.
  • It differs from Colles' fracture in that the distal fragment displaces and tilts volarly.
  • Treatment is by closed reduction and above-elbow plaster cast immobilisation for 6 weeks. Grossly displaced fractures might need ORIF.

Explanation of other options:

Colles fracture (Option A): A fracture occurring in adults, at the cortico-cancellous junction of the distal end of the radius with dorsal tilt and other displacement.

Barton fracture (Option B): Intra-articular fractures through the distal articular surface of the radius, taking a margin, anterior or posterior, of the distal radius with the carpals, displaced anteriorly or posteriorly.

Chauffer fracture (Option D): An intra-articular, oblique fracture of the styloid process of the radius.

questions.text: A 40-year-old lady presents with pain on the radial side of the wrist, explained to be worsened with activities like pruning roses or wringing out clothes. On examination clinician performs the manoeuvre shown in the figure. Which clinical test is elicited?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical test performed is the Finkelstein test, which is the pathognomonic test for De Quervain tenosynovitis..

De Quervain tenosynovitis:

  • De Quervain tenosynovitis is a condition characterised by tenosynovitis of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis (first dorsal compartment) tendons of the wrist.
  • Clinical features: Pain and swelling over the radial styloid process.
  • On examination, the tenderness is localised to the radial styloid process, and there may be a palpable thickening of the sheath.
  • Pain is aggravated by adducting the thumb across the palm and forcing ulnar deviation, and on asking the patient to perform radial deviation against resistance. This is Finkelstein's test for De Quervain tenosynovitis.

Treatment:

  • The early case can be relieved by a corticosteroid injection into the tendon sheath, sometimes combined with hand therapy (ultrasound, frictions, splintage).
  • Resistant cases need an operation, which consists of slitting the thickened tendon sheath.

Explanation of other options:

Compound palmar ganglia (Option A): This lesion is neither a ganglion nor compound. Chronic inflammation distends the common sheath of the flexor tendons both above and below the flexor retinaculum. Rheumatoid arthritis and tuberculosis are the commonest causes. Pain is unusual, but paraesthesia due to median nerve compression may occur. A characteristic hourglass swelling bulging above and below the flexor retinaculum is seen.

Carpal tunnel syndrome (Option B): This is a syndrome characterised by the compression of the median nerve as it passes beneath the flexor retinaculum. The patient is generally a middle-aged woman complaining of tingling, numbness or discomfort in the thumb and radial one and a half fingers, e., in the median nerve distribution. These symptoms can be elicited by Phalen's test.

Tennis elbow (Option D): This is a condition characterised by pain and tenderness at the lateral epicondyle of the humerus due to non-specific inflammation at the origin of the extensor muscles of the forearm. Cozen's test is a clinical test to diagnose tennis elbow.

questions.text: All of the following displacements are seen in Colle's fracture except -
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Medial Displacement is not seen in Colle's fracture.

In a Colles fracture, the fracture line runs transversely at the cortico-cancellous junction of the distal radius. In the majority of cases, one or more of the following displacements of the distal fragment occur:

  • Dorsal displacement (Dorsal shift)
  • Dorsal tilt (Dorsal angulation) (Option A)
  • Lateral displacement (lateral shift)
  • Lateral tilt (lateral angulation)
  • Supination (external rotation) (Option C)
  • Impaction (proximal migration) (Option B)

questions.text: A 40-year-old man complains of pain around the wrist after a fall. On examination, the distal end of the ulna appeared prominent and was found to move up and down on firmly pressing the prominence. This clinical sign is suggestive of instability of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical sign explained is the Piano key sign, which is performed for assessing distal radio-ulnar joint instability.

Piano-Key Sign:

  • The test is carried out for the clinical assessment of wrist instability. It is used as an indicator for distal radio-ulnar joint instability and tears of the triangular fibrocartilage complex of the wrist.
  • In the Piano-key Sign Test, the wrist is supported in pronation, and the hand is stabilised in the neutral position. Force is applied to the head of the ulna.
  • The test is positive if the ulnar head goes back to its anatomic position after the removal of the force applied to the ulnar head.
  • This bears resemblance to when a piano key springs up after the force from a finger is removed from the key, hence, the name 'piano-key' sign. This instability and pain are judged relative to the contralateral wrist.
  • No instability or movement was observed on the removal of pressure on the ulnar head.

choices.text: Thumb metacarpophalangeal joint, ulnar collateral ligament rupture
Thumb metacarpophalangeal joint radial collateral ligament rupture
Thumb interphalangeal joint, ulnar collateral ligament rupture
Thumb interphalangeal joint, radial collateral ligament rupture

questions.text: A 30-year-old skier presents with pain and swelling around the base of his thumb after a fall while holding his ski pole. On examination, there is tenderness over the ulnar aspect of the base of the thumb. Which is the most likely involved joint and cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Injury to the ulnar collateral ligament of the 1st metacarpophalangeal joint (thumb) is most likely involved mechanism; this is commonly referred to as gamekeeper's thumb or skier's thumb.

Gamekeeper's thumb:

  • Snow skiing accidents and falls on an outstretched hand with forceful radial and palmar abduction of the thumb are the usual causes.
  • Sometimes, there is an associated soft tissue injury called a Stener lesion.
  • On examination, there is tenderness and swelling precisely over the ulnar side of the thumb metacarpophalangeal joint.

Treatment:

  • Partial tears can be treated by a short period (2-4 weeks) of immobilisation in a splint, followed by increasing movement.
  • Complete tears need operative repair. Postoperatively, the joint is immobilised in a thumb splint for 6 weeks.

choices.text: Superficial branch of the radial nerve

questions.text: On examination of a patient with wrist pain following trauma, tenderness is noted in the anatomical snuff box. Which of the following structures is a content of this space?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The only content of the snuff box is the Radial artery.

Anatomical snuff box (scaphoid fossa):

  • It is a triangularly shaped space formed by the tendons that extend the thumb.
  • It has three borders, a floor, and a roof:
    • Ulnar (medial) border: Tendon of the extensor pollicis longus.
    • Radial (lateral) border: Tendons of the extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus.
    • Proximal border: Styloid process of the radius.
    • Floor: Carpal bones; scaphoid and trapezium.
    • Roof: Skin.
  • The main content of the anatomical snuff box is the radial artery.
  • Tenderness in the anatomical snuff box is the most common clinical sign associated with scaphoid fracture.

Explanation of other options:

Ulnar artery (Option B): The ulnar artery travels along the ulna, and in the palm, it passes superficial to the flexor retinaculum to form the superficial palmar arch.

Median nerve (Option C): The Median nerve passes under the carpal tunnel in the wrist along with the flexor tendons.

Superficial branch of radial nerve (Option C): The superficial branch of radial nerve, along with the cephalic vein, passes through the roof of the anatomical snuff box, but it is not a content of this space.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chauffer's fracture, also called Hutchinson fracture or backfire fracture, is the intra-articular fracture of the radial head.

Bennet fracture: An intra-articular fracture at the base of the first metacarpal. This fracture typically involves displacement of the metacarpal shaft due to the pull of the abductor pollicis longus muscle. Treated with the Wagner technique of closed reduction and percutaneous K-wire fixation.

Rolando fracture is an intra-articular fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y-shaped comminuted fracture. Treatment includes open reduction, plate fixation, and sometimes the use of K-wires.

Boxer's fracture typically involves fracture of the neck of the 5th metacarpal and is usually managed with immobilisation with James' position cast.

Eponym Fractures of the upper limb:

choices.text: Rupture of the extensor pollicis longus tendon

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman with an alleged history of a slip and fall presents to the ER with pain and deformity of the right wrist. X-ray revealed a transverse fracture of the distal radius with a dorsal displacement of the distal fragment. What is the most common complication associated with this fracture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A transverse fracture of the distal end of the radius with a dorsal displacement of the distal fragment, especially in an elderly woman, is suggestive of Colle's fracture. The most common complication associated with Colle's fracture is joint stiffness, especially finger stiffness.

Complications of Colle's fracture:

  • Stiffness of joints: Finger stiffness is the most common complication; the shoulder, wrist, and elbow are other joints that commonly become stiff. This occurs because of a lack of exercise and can be prevented by actively moving these joints.
  • Malunion
  • Sudeck's osteodystrophy (reflex sympathetic dystrophy)
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome
  • Rupture of the extensor pollicis longus tendon
  • Carpal instability
  • Triangular Fibrocartilage Complex injury

Sudeck's osteodystrophy (reflex sympathetic dystrophy): Colles' fracture is the commonest cause of Sudeck's dystrophy in the upper limb. The patient complains of pain, stiffness, and swelling of the hand. The overlying skin appears stretched and glossy. Treatment is by intensive physiotherapy.

Explanation of other options:

Malunion (Option A): It is the second most common complication. It results in a dinner fork deformity.

Avascular necrosis (Option B): Avascular necrosis is never a complication seen with Colle's fracture. It is commonly seen in scaphoid fracture, fracture of the talus, and fracture neck of the femur.

Rupture of the pollicis longus tendon (Option D): This is an extremely rare complication of fracture and is either due to loss of blood supply to the tendon at the time of fracture or due to the friction the tendon is subjected to every time it moves over a malunited fracture. Treatment is by tendon transfer (extensor indicis to extensor pollicis longus).

Key Takeaways:

  • Most common complication of Colles fracture → Finger stiffness,
  • 2nd most common complication of Colles fracture → Malunion

choices.text: Fracture dislocation of the MCP joint of the thumb
IP fracture dislocation of the thumb
Anterior marginal fracture of the distal end of the radius
Fracture dislocation of the trapeziometacarpal joint

questions.text: Identify the fracture shown in the given X-ray:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

X-ray shows a fracture base of the first metacarpal with dislocation of the metacarpal.

The trapeziometacarpal joint is the same as the 1st CMC joint, and Bennett's fracture involves the 1st CMC joint.

Bennett's fracture-dislocation:

  • This is an oblique intraarticular fracture of the base of the first metacarpal, a kind of carpo-metacarpal fracture dislocation in which the distal diaphyseal fragment is displaced laterally, proximally and dorsally by the combined pull of the abductor pollicis longus (primarily) and adductor pollicis.
  • It is the most common of all fractures of the base of the thumb.
  • Another fracture that involves the same area is the Rolando fracture, which is a T/Y pattern comminuted intra-articular fracture of the base of the 1st metacarpal.

Explanation of other options:

Fracture dislocation of the MCP joint of the thumb (Option A): The metacarpophalangeal joint is between the first metacarpal and the proximal phalanx of the thumb. This option refers to a fracture around the MCP joint, accompanied by dislocation. Not typical of Bennett's or Rolando's fractures, which involve the base of the first metacarpal and the trapeziometacarpal (CMC) joint.

IP fracture dislocation of the thumb (Option B): This involves a fracture around the interphalangeal joints, typically seen in crush injuries or hyperextension trauma.

Anterior marginal fracture of the distal end of the radius: (Option C): Refers to a fracture involving the volar (anterior) lip of the distal radius, often associated with a volar Barton's fracture.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a deformity shown in the image below. The preferred treatment for the correction of deformity is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The deformity shown in the image is cubitus varus deformity, also known as gunstock deformity. It is treated primarily with lateral closing wedge osteotomy.

Cubitus varus deformity:

  • The deformity is most obvious when the elbow is extended and the arms are elevated. The most common cause is malunion of a supracondylar fracture in childhood.
  • Cubitus varus deformity can be treated with lateral closing wedge osteotomy. A named lateral closing wedge osteotomy is the French osteotomy.

Explanation of other options:

Medial closing wedge osteotomy (Option A), lateral opening wedge osteotomy (Option D): Cubitus valgus is treated with medial closing wedge osteotomy or lateral opening wedge osteotomy

Medial opening wedge osteotomy(Option C): It is also used for treating cubitus varus, but is less preferred, because of the high risk of complications related to bone healing, like non-union. Generally, closing wedge osteotomies are preferred over open wedge osteotomies.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male falls on his outstretched hand during a football game and presents with severe pain and swelling around the right elbow. On examination, the three-point relation around the elbow joint is disrupted. X-ray confirms a dislocation of the elbow. Among the following, all are complications of elbow dislocation except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Radial nerve injury is not usually seen in elbow dislocations. Radial nerve injuries are commonly seen with the fracture of shaft of humerus.

Complications of elbow dislocations: .

Early complications

  • Vascular injury. - The brachial artery is the structure at risk. It may result in compartment syndrome and Volkmann's ischemic contracture.
  • Nerve injury-- Median and ulnar nerve injury can occur.

Late complications

  • Stiffness
  • Myositis ossificans
  • Unreduced dislocation
  • Recurrent dislocation

Explanation of other options:

Myositis ossificans (Option A): This is the ossification of the haematoma around a joint, resulting in the formation of a mass of bone that restricts joint movements, often completely. It is commonly seen in elbow dislocation and supracondylar fracture of the humerus.

Median nerve injury (Option B): The median or ulnar nerve is sometimes injured. Spontaneous recovery usually occurs after 6-8 weeks.

Brachial artery injury(Option A): The brachial artery may be damaged in elbow dislocation. Absence of the radial pulse is a warning. If there are other signs of ischaemia, the injury should be treated as an emergency; the brachial artery may have to be explored by an appropriately trained surgeon.

questions.text: A 50-year-old carpenter has been working continuously in an under-construction house for 1 month. He now complains of pain in the lateral aspect of his elbow while working. On examination, there is tenderness on the lateral epicondyle. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient is suffering from pain in the elbow, and there is tenderness on the lateral epicondyle. This is most probably lateral epicondylitis, also called the tennis elbow.

Tennis elbow:

  • Tennis elbow is the tendinosis and inflammation of the origin of the common extensor tendons.
  • It is caused by to overuse of wrist extension.
  • It can be seen in tennis players and manual labourers and is the most common cause of elbow pain in adults.
  • MC muscle involved - Extensor carpi radialis brevis, and the first change of tennis elbow occurs in the extensor carpi radialis brevis muscle.
  • Treatment: Rest, counterforce brace and exercises. If this does not work, then local steroid injections are given.

Explanation of other options:

Stress fracture elbow (Option A): Stress fractures of the elbow are rare and occur due to repetitive or high-impact upper limb activities. The most common site of elbow stress fracture is the olecranon, caused by repetitive traction from the triceps muscle during forceful extension.

Golfer's elbow (Option C): Golfer's elbow results from inflammation at the origin of the flexor tendons at the medial epicondyle of the humerus. Tenderness over the medial epicondyle and pain on resisted forearm pronation in extension are diagnostic. Treatment involves rest, exercises and counterbraces; steroid injections are considered a last resort.

Osteoarthritis of the elbow (Option D): The most common complaint from patients with elbow osteoarthritis is loss of range of movement. Osteoarthritis of the elbow can occur secondary to fracture, dislocation, or inflammatory arthritis.

questions.text: Identify the brace shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a counterforce brace, which is used in the treatment of both tennis elbow and golfer's elbow.

Counterforce brace acts by offloading the lateral epicondyle and giving it rest till the inflammation subsides.

Explanation of other options:

Turn buckle splint (Option A): Also known as the Volkmann splint, it is used to treat muscle and joint contractures seen in conditions like Volkmann ischemic contracture. It acts by assisting the passive stretching of contracted muscles.

Cockup splint (Option C): These splints are used in radial nerve palsy to prevent wrist drop.

Taylor brace (Option D): The Taylor brace is useful in the prevention of pathological fractures in a severely osteoporotic spine. They provide dorsolumbar stabilisation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady presents with complaints of pain over the lateral aspect of the elbow. She explains that the pain worsens while lifting objects and squeezing clothes. On examination, pain is elicited with resisted wrist extension. Which of the following tests is not used in the evaluation of this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical features of lateral elbow pain worsening with lifting of objects are suggestive of tennis elbow.
  • The Finkelstein test is a test for De Quervain tenosynovitis and is not used to evaluate tennis elbow.
  • Wrist extension against resistance causing pain indicates a positive Cozen's test - a clinical test for tennis elbow.

Tests for tennis elbow:

  • Cozen's test - Wrist extension against resistance causes pain (Option A ruled out)
  • Maudsley test - Middle finger extension against resistance causes pain (Option D ruled out)
  • Mills' test - Passive palmar flexion of the wrist with extended elbow causes pain (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: A 23-year-old doctor had been preparing for the upcoming entrance exam for the last 3 months. Now he develops a swelling in the right elbow, as seen in the image. O/E, the swelling is cystic and located over the olecranon process. The elbow movements are normal. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows olecranon bursitis, which usually occurs in students who write a lot while resting their elbow on the desk.

Olecranon bursitis

  • It is also called the student's elbow.
  • Result from repeated pressure or friction over the olecranon, causing the olecranon bursa to become enlarged and inflamed.
  • It usually occurs in students who write a lot while resting their elbows on the desk.
  • The most common non-traumatic cause is gout; there may be a sizeable lump with calcification on X-ray.
  • Treatment is rest and NSAIDs.

Explanation of other options:

Elbow joint effusion (Option A): This would typically cause restricted range of motion, and the swelling would be more generalised around the joint, not focal over the olecranon.

Septic arthritis of the elbow (Option C): Septic arthritis presents with a severe throbbing pain, swelling and redness of the affected joint. There will be associated fever and malaise.

questions.text: A 24-year-old football player, following a fall while playing, complains of pain and swelling around the right wrist. On examination, there is tenderness over the scaphoid fossa. Which carpel bone is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tenderness in the scaphoid fossa following a fall on an outstretched hand is typical of scaphoid fracture.

Scaphoid fracture:

  • The scaphoid is the most commonly fractured carpal bone.
  • These patients present with pain & swelling over the radial aspect of the wrist following a fall on out stretched hand.
  • The most important clinical sign is tenderness in the anatomical snuff box (scaphoid fossa).
  • Oblique view of the wrist is the best radiographic view to diagnose it. However, X-ray changes may not be visible for 2-3 weeks.
  • Sites of fracture in scaphoid fracture:
    • Distal pole - most common in children
    • Waist - most common in adults: the waist of the scaphoid is at the junction of the anterior & mid one-thirds
    • Proximal pole - most commonly associated with complications

Treatment:

  • Undisplaced fracture: The affected hand is immobilised in a scaphoid cast for 3-4 months.
  • Scaphoid cast: This is a cast extending from below the elbow to the metacarpal heads, including the thumb, up to the interphalangeal joint. The wrist is maintained in a little dorsiflexion and radial deviation (glass holding position).
  • Displaced fracture: In widely displaced fractures, open reduction and internal fixation using a special compression screw (Herbert's screw) is required.

Common complications of scaphoid fractures :

  • Non union
  • Avascular necrosis
